comments.author: Aakash Shah
comments.text: LEARNED: Never chain rebase+merge for multiple agent branches in one command. Do them one at a time: (1) stash dirty state, (2) rebase one branch onto main, (3) ff-only merge, (4) repeat for next branch, (5) stash pop. Also remove worktrees BEFORE attempting rebase — git rebase fails if the branch is checked out in any worktree. The safe sequence is: git worktree remove --force, then git stash, then git rebase main <branch>, then git merge --ff-only <branch>, then git branch -d <branch>.

title: P0: oro stop SIGINT bypass — agents can still kill dispatcher via oro stop
description:
## Problem
Agents can still kill the dispatcher by running `oro stop`, which sends SIGINT — a signal the daemon always honors. The 3-layer defense blocks the shutdown *directive*, but SIGINT bypasses all of it.

## Fix
Add an interactive confirmation prompt to `oro stop` that requires typing "yes" on stdin. Since Claude Code Bash tool cannot interact with stdin prompts, agents will be unable to complete the confirmation.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `oro stop` prompts for interactive confirmation ("Type YES to confirm shutdown:") before sending SIGINT
- [ ] The confirmation reads from stdin and requires exact match "YES"
- [ ] If stdin is not a TTY (piped input), `oro stop` refuses to run with an error message
- [ ] `oro stop --force` flag exists for automation but ONLY works when ORO_HUMAN_CONFIRMED env var is set (defense in depth)
- [ ] Existing tests updated to reflect the new confirmation flow
- [ ] Manual test: running `oro stop` in a non-interactive shell (like Claude Code Bash) fails with clear error
close_reason: Fixed: added interactive TTY confirmation to oro stop and oro cleanup. Agents can no longer bypass.

comments.author: Aakash Shah

title: Add step-by-step startup log with spinner to oro start
description:
## Context

`oro start` takes 60-120 seconds with ZERO user feedback until the final
'oro swarm started' line. Add a step-by-step log that prints each phase
as it completes, with an animated spinner during long waits.

## Target output

```
✓ Preflight checks passed
✓ Daemon started (PID 1234)
✓ Dispatcher socket ready
⠋ Waiting for architect...        ← spinner animates during ~30-45s wait
✓ Architect ready (34s)
⠋ Waiting for manager...
✓ Manager ready (31s)
✓ Beacon verified
oro swarm started (PID 1234, workers=2, model=sonnet)
```

## Implementation

### 1. Add a startup logger helper in cmd/oro/startup_log.go

Create a small `startupLog` struct with methods:
- `Step(msg string)` — prints `✓ <msg>` with green checkmark
- `StepTimed(msg string, d time.Duration)` — prints `✓ <msg> (Xs)` 
- `StartSpinner(msg string) func()` — starts goroutine printing braille spinner
  `⠋⠙⠹⠸⠼⠴⠦⠧⠇⠏` at ~80ms interval on same line via `\r`. Returns a stop func
  that kills spinner and prints the final `✓` line.
- Non-TTY fallback: check `isatty.IsTerminal(os.Stdout.Fd())` — if false, just
  print static lines without spinner animation. `go-isatty` already imported.
- Use `context.Context` for cancellation — stop func cancels spinner goroutine.

### 2. Wire into cmd/oro/cmd_start.go

In `runFullStart()` (line ~98):

```go
log := newStartupLog(os.Stdout)
```

Insert calls at each phase boundary:
- After `preflightAndCheckRunning()` returns: `log.Step("Preflight checks passed")`
- After `SpawnDaemon()` returns: `log.Step(fmt.Sprintf("Daemon started (PID %d)", pid))`
- Before socket poll loop (line 113): `stop := log.StartSpinner("Waiting for dispatcher socket...")`
- After socket ready: `stop()` then `log.Step("Dispatcher socket ready")`
- Inside `TmuxSession.Create()` — needs a callback or logger interface passed in:
  - Before each `WaitForPrompt`: `stop := log.StartSpinner(fmt.Sprintf("Waiting for %s...", role))`
  - After prompt ready: `stop()` then `log.StepTimed(fmt.Sprintf("%s ready", role), elapsed)`
  - Before `VerifyBeaconReceived`: `stop := log.StartSpinner("Verifying beacon...")`
  - After beacon verified: `stop()` then `log.Step("Beacon verified")`
- Keep existing final line: `"oro swarm started (PID %d, workers=%d, model=%s)\n"`

### 3. Pass logger into TmuxSession.Create

`TmuxSession.Create()` in `tmux.go:200` is where the long waits happen. Either:
- Add a `Logger` field to `TmuxSession` struct, or
- Add a `StartupLogger` parameter to `Create()`
- The logger interface: `type StartupLogger interface { Step(string); StepTimed(string, time.Duration); StartSpinner(string) func() }`

### Key files
- `cmd/oro/cmd_start.go` — runFullStart() orchestrator (line ~98-147)
- `cmd/oro/tmux.go` — TmuxSession.Create() (line ~200), WaitForPrompt, SendKeysVerified
- `cmd/oro/startup_log.go` — NEW file for startupLog helper
- `cmd/oro/startup_log_test.go` — NEW file for tests

### Non-TTY handling
`go-isatty` is already imported in cmd_start.go. When stdout is not a TTY:
- Skip spinner animation entirely
- Print static lines: "Waiting for architect..." then "✓ Architect ready (34s)"

## Acceptance criteria
1. `oro start` prints step-by-step progress including ✓ checkmarks for completed phases
2. Long-wait phases (pane readiness) show an animated braille spinner that updates in-place
3. Non-TTY output (piped) degrades gracefully to static lines without ANSI escape codes
4. No spinner goroutine leaks — all spinners cleaned up on error paths and normal completion
acceptance_criteria: oro start prints step-by-step progress including ✓ checkmarks for completed phases; Long-wait phases (pane readiness) show an animated braille spinner that updates in-place; Non-TTY output (piped) degrades gracefully to static lines without ANSI escape codes; No spinner goroutine leaks — all spinners cleaned up on error paths and normal completion; Tests verify spinner behavior in TTY and non-TTY modes; Manual test: oro start shows expected output with spinners and timing

Progress timeout may be too aggressive for this bead size.

title: Write comprehensive README with philosophy, architecture, features, and CLI reference
description:
## Problem

The current README.md is a stub — 17 lines of cryptic notes and installation hints. Oro is a substantial agent swarm orchestrator with 14 CLI commands, a memory system, a dispatcher, quality gates, and a multi-agent tmux architecture. None of this is documented for new users or contributors.

## Current README

\`\`\`
go
context7 mcp
beads dolt
brew install beads dolt
brew install golangci-lint
...
oro - oroboros
minimal, lightweight
context managing
eats itself forever
\`\`\`

## Design

Write a comprehensive README.md covering:

### 1. Philosophy (2-3 paragraphs)
- Oro = Ouroboros — a self-managing agent swarm that eats its own tail
- Autonomous multi-agent orchestration: architect designs, manager coordinates, workers execute
- Opinionated quality: TDD, quality gates, code review baked into the workflow
- Memory system: learnings persist across sessions, agents learn from past mistakes

### 2. Architecture Overview
- Diagram: Human → Architect (tmux pane) → Manager (tmux pane) → Dispatcher (daemon) → Workers (claude -p)
- Bead system: work items with acceptance criteria, dependencies, parent-child relationships
- Quality gate: automated lint/test/format pipeline that workers must pass
- Memory: 3-layer system (bead annotations, handoffs, project memory with FTS5)

### 3. Quick Start
- Prerequisites: Go, Claude Code CLI, beads (bd), dolt, golangci-lint
- \`oro init\` → \`oro start\`
- What happens: tmux session with architect + manager, dispatcher daemon, worker pool

### 4. CLI Reference
Categorized command list (same as help command design):
- Lifecycle: init, start, stop, cleanup
- Monitoring: status, logs, dash
- Memory: remember, recall, forget, memories
- Control: directive
- Search: index

### 5. Key Concepts
- Beads: work items tracked by \`bd\` CLI
- Epics: parent beads that group related work
- Quality Gate: automated checks before merge
- Worktrees: isolated git worktrees per worker
- Handoffs: context transfer between worker sessions

### 6. Development
- \`make build\` / \`make test\`
- Project structure: cmd/oro/, pkg/dispatcher/, pkg/memory/, pkg/worker/, pkg/ops/

## Files to Modify
- README.md — Rewrite from scratch

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] README contains sections: Philosophy, Architecture, Quick Start, CLI Reference, Key Concepts, Development
- [ ] All 14 CLI commands are documented with usage examples
- [ ] Architecture diagram (ASCII or text-based) showing component relationships
- [ ] Quick Start section is copy-pasteable (working commands)

Read: README.md, cmd/oro/root.go:newRootCmd (for CLI description), docs/plans/2026-02-07-memory-system-spec.md (for memory architecture), cmd/oro/cmd_start.go (for start flow)
close_reason: README rewritten with Philosophy, Architecture (ASCII diagram), Quick Start, CLI Reference (all 15 commands), Key Concepts, Development sections. Commit: 9adc5db

title: Epic: Concurrency Hardening
description: Fix data-loss and deadlock bugs in dispatcher and worker concurrency. Reservation pattern for lock-unlock-pray, WaitGroup for goroutine lifecycle, timer/goroutine leak fixes.

title: Replace lock-unlock-pray with two-phase reservation pattern
description:
**Spec ref:** docs/plans/2026-02-10-hardening-spec.md §1.1

**Problem:** Dispatcher acquires mutex, reads state, releases for I/O (memory.ForPrompt), re-acquires, hopes nothing changed. checkHeartbeats can delete worker during unlock window, silently losing bead assignments. testUnlockHook exists to reproduce this — team knows it's broken. Affects: registerWorker (lines 388-450), handleQGFailure (lines 548-607), handleDone (lines 492-542), handleReviewResult (lines 860-904).

**Design:** Add WorkerReserved state. Under lock: set worker to Reserved (heartbeat checker skips reserved workers). Release lock for I/O. Re-acquire lock: verify reservation still valid, transition to Busy, send ASSIGN.

**Files:** pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go, pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher_test.go

**Acceptance:**
- Test: pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher_test.go:TestReservationPattern | Cmd: go test -race -count=5 ./pkg/dispatcher/... | Assert: WorkerReserved state prevents heartbeat deletion during I/O window
- All 4 lock-release-relock sites converted
- testUnlockHook still works
- Existing tests pass unchanged
close_reason: Tests pass with -race -count=5. All 4 sites converted to reservation pattern.

title: Add defer to merge abortMu lock — prevent panic deadlock
description:
**Spec ref:** docs/plans/2026-02-10-hardening-spec.md §1.2

**Problem:** pkg/merge/merge.go lines 72-83: abortMu.Lock() without defer. Panic between lock/unlock deadlocks all future Abort() calls permanently. In a merge coordinator handling rebase conflicts, panics are real.

**Design:** Wrap abortMu lock/unlock pairs in closure with defer. Both in Merge() setup (line 76-77) and the deferred cleanup (line 80-82).

**Files:** pkg/merge/merge.go, pkg/merge/merge_test.go

**Acceptance:**
- Test: pkg/merge/merge_test.go:TestAbortMu_PanicSafety | Cmd: go test -race ./pkg/merge/... | Assert: panic between lock/unlock does not deadlock subsequent Abort() calls
- All abortMu.Lock() paired with defer in same scope
close_reason: Tests pass. All abortMu.Lock() paired with defer.

title: Add sync.WaitGroup goroutine tracking to dispatcher
description:
**Spec ref:** docs/plans/2026-02-10-hardening-spec.md §1.3

**Problem:** Dispatcher Run() spawns 3+ long-lived goroutines and N event-driven goroutines, tracks none with WaitGroup. Run() returns while goroutines still running — test flakes, resource leaks on shutdown, merge results lost. Also: acceptLoop spawns unbounded goroutines per connection (no semaphore).

**Design:** Add wg sync.WaitGroup to Dispatcher. Every go call: wg.Add(1)/defer wg.Done(). Run() waits wg.Wait() with 5s timeout before returning. Add bounded semaphore (100) for connection handlers in acceptLoop.

**Files:** pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go, pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher_test.go

**Acceptance:**
- Test: pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher_test.go:TestRunWaitsForGoroutines | Cmd: go test -race ./pkg/dispatcher/... | Assert: Run() does not return until all goroutines exit (within 5s timeout)
- Test: TestAcceptLoopBackpressure | Assert: 101st concurrent connection blocks until slot opens
- All go calls wrapped with wg tracking
close_reason: All goroutines tracked with WaitGroup. Semaphore limits concurrent connections to 100. Run() waits up to 5s for goroutines to finish. All tests pass with race detector.

title: Add context cancellation to GracefulShutdownWorker goroutine

title: Fix stale handoff_requested signal persisting across sessions
description:
## Problem
The pane_handoff_reminder.py PreToolUse hook fires on EVERY tool call in new sessions because
~/.oro/panes/<role>/handoff_requested signal file persists across sessions. The dispatcher's
restartPane() cleans it, but only during explicit pane restarts — not when a user starts a
new manual session. Result: every tool call gets a "CRITICAL: Context threshold reached"
warning even at 17% context.

## Root Cause
1. Dispatcher creates handoff_requested when context_pct exceeds threshold
2. Session ends (terminal closed, /clear, etc.)
3. New session starts — signal file still exists
4. pane_handoff_reminder.py checks file existence only, no context_pct guard
5. Every PreToolUse injects the critical warning

## Fix (two layers)

### Layer 1: SessionStart cleanup (session_start_extras.py)
In main(), after determining oro_role, delete handoff_requested if it exists:
```python
# Clean stale handoff signals from previous session
if oro_role:
    signal = Path(PANES_DIR) / oro_role / "handoff_requested"
    with contextlib.suppress(OSError):
        signal.unlink(missing_ok=True)
```
Insert after line ~497 (after `oro_role = os.environ.get("ORO_ROLE", "")`).

### Layer 2: Defense-in-depth guard (pane_handoff_reminder.py)
Also check context_pct before firing. Only inject the warning if context_pct > 40:
```python
# Guard: only fire if context_pct is actually high
context_pct_file = panes_dir / role / "context_pct"
try:
    pct = int(context_pct_file.read_text().strip())
    if pct < 40:
        return  # Signal is stale, context is fresh
except (OSError, ValueError):
    return  # Can't read pct, don't fire
```
Insert in main() after _check_signal() returns True, before building the context string.

## Files
- assets/hooks/session_start_extras.py (add cleanup in main)
- assets/hooks/pane_handoff_reminder.py (add context_pct guard)
- ~/.oro/hooks/session_start_extras.py (installed copy)
- ~/.oro/hooks/pane_handoff_reminder.py (installed copy)
- tests/test_pane_handoff_reminder.py or similar (new test)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] New session cleans up handoff_requested signal on SessionStart
- [ ] pane_handoff_reminder only fires when context_pct > 40%
- [ ] Test: signal file exists + context_pct=19 → hook returns no output
- [ ] Test: signal file exists + context_pct=55 → hook returns critical warning
close_reason: Tests pass, implementation complete. Commit: 673c518

title: Add post-injection beacon health check — verify Claude sessions received beacons
description:
## Problem
After beacon injection (tmux.go:83-89), nothing verifies the Claude sessions actually received and are processing the beacons. If injection silently fails (wrong pane state, Claude crashed, text truncated by tmux buffer), the swarm starts with lobotomized architect/manager sessions that don't know their roles.

## Current Flow
1. Inject beacon text via `tmux send-keys`
2. Return success immediately
3. `oro start` prints "swarm started" — no validation

## Desired Flow
1. Inject beacon text via `tmux send-keys`
2. Poll pane output for evidence that Claude is processing the beacon
3. For manager: look for `bd stats` execution (manager beacon step 1 runs this)
4. For architect: look for acknowledgment text or tool usage
5. Return success only after both sessions show activity
6. Timeout after 60s with clear error

## Design Notes
- Manager beacon instructs: "Run `bd stats`" as step 1 — we can watch for `bd stats` output in the pane
- Architect beacon is more passive — may need to look for Claude's "thinking" indicator or first tool call
- Use `tmux capture-pane -p -t <pane>` to read pane content
- This check runs AFTER readiness polling (depends on oro-XXX beacon readiness bead)
- Consider: should `oro start` print "waiting for sessions..." during this phase?

## Graceful Failure
- If manager doesn't start executing within 60s: print warning but don't kill the session (human can manually intervene)
- If architect doesn't show activity within 60s: print warning (architect is human-driven, so it may just be idle)
- Differentiate between "beacon not received" (no Claude activity) and "beacon received but execution slow" (Claude is thinking)
- Log the pane capture at timeout for debugging

## Files
- cmd/oro/tmux.go (add health check after injection)
- cmd/oro/tmux_test.go (test health check flow)
- cmd/oro/cmd_start.go (integrate health check into startup flow, surface warnings)

## Acceptance Criteria
- After beacon injection, `oro start` polls for manager activity (bd stats output)
- Timeout produces a warning (not a hard failure) with diagnostic info
- Tests cover: healthy startup, manager timeout, pane capture failure
- `go test ./cmd/oro/... -run TestTmux` passes
close_reason: Added VerifyBeaconReceived that polls pane content for manager activity after beacon injection

title: Prune bead tracking maps on worker connection close
description:
handleConn deferred cleanup (dispatcher.go:513-520) calls delete(d.workers, workerID) but never calls clearBeadTracking(beadID). When a worker process dies and its TCP connection drops, the scanner EOF triggers the deferred cleanup, removing the worker from d.workers. But BeadTracker maps (attemptCounts, qgStuckTracker, escalatedBeads, etc.) retain stale entries. Since the worker is already gone from d.workers, checkHeartbeats never sees it, so clearBeadTracking never fires for the connection-drop path. The hourly pruneStaleTracking safety net is too slow — stale qgStuckTracker entries cause false STUCK detections and stale escalatedBeads entries suppress legitimate escalations.

Fix: In handleConn's deferred cleanup, before calling delete(d.workers, workerID), capture w.beadID. After deleting, if beadID \!= empty, call clearBeadTracking(beadID).

title: Unify bead quality into single bead-craft skill (replaces spec-to-beads)
description:
Replace spec-to-beads with a unified bead-craft skill that defines bead quality ONCE and serves three modes: decompose, create, review.

## Problem
Bead quality logic is scattered: size heuristics in spec-to-beads AND work-bead, acceptance format in spec-to-beads only, no review capability at all. Adding Rule of Five to just spec-to-beads would fracture it further.

## Design

### Single skill: .claude/skills/bead-craft/SKILL.md
Three modes triggered by context:

**Decompose** (was spec-to-beads): spec/design → bead dependency graph
**Create**: ad-hoc single bead with full quality applied  
**Review**: audit existing beads via bd list, flag smells

### Shared quality core (all modes use this):

1. Bead anatomy — required fields, enriched acceptance format:
   Test: path:FnName | Cmd: test_cmd | Assert: expected
   Read: file1.go:Symbol1, file2.go:Symbol2
   Signature: func Name(ctx context.Context, arg Type) (Result, error)
   Edges: nil input → ErrInvalid; timeout → context.DeadlineExceeded

2. Rule of Five critique loop — 5 passes on every bead before emitting:
   P1 Zero Ambiguity: exact signatures, types, error conditions
   P2 TDD Inputs/Outputs: concrete test data, not vague assertions
   P3 Context Minimization: exact files and symbols worker must read
   P4 Boundary Check: IPC/RPC crossings get protocol + both sides specified
   P5 Adversarial: what would a zero-context worker misunderstand?

3. Size heuristics — >7min, >4 files, 'and' in title, multiple unrelated assertions → decompose

4. Smell catalog (for review mode):
   - No acceptance criteria
   - Vague title ('improve X', 'handle edge cases')
   - Missing Read: field (worker doesn't know what to look at)
   - >3 days stale in_progress
   - Estimate missing
   - Depends on closed bead (stale dep)

### Migration
- Delete .claude/skills/spec-to-beads/ directory
- Create .claude/skills/bead-craft/ directory with SKILL.md
- Update work-bead SKILL.md to reference bead-craft for size heuristics instead of inlining them
- Update any skill that references spec-to-beads (using-skills routing table, workflow-routing)

## Files
- .claude/skills/bead-craft/SKILL.md (new, replaces spec-to-beads)
- .claude/skills/spec-to-beads/SKILL.md (delete)
- .claude/skills/work-bead/SKILL.md (remove inlined size heuristics, reference bead-craft)
- .claude/skills/using-skills/SKILL.md (update routing table)
- .claude/skills/workflow-routing/SKILL.md (update if references spec-to-beads)

## Acceptance
Test: manual | Cmd: ls .claude/skills/bead-craft/SKILL.md && \! ls .claude/skills/spec-to-beads/SKILL.md 2>/dev/null | Assert: bead-craft exists, spec-to-beads gone
Verify: grep -c 'Rule of Five\|Zero Ambiguity\|Boundary Check\|Smell' .claude/skills/bead-craft/SKILL.md >= 6
Verify: grep 'bead-craft' .claude/skills/work-bead/SKILL.md confirms cross-reference
Verify: no remaining references to spec-to-beads in any SKILL.md

title: Add spawn-for directive to launch a worker for a specific bead
description:
Add an 'oro directive spawn-for <bead-id>' command that spawns a single worker and force-assigns it to a specific bead, bypassing the dispatcher's normal queue. This enables the manager to guarantee a P0 bead gets worked immediately without relying on scale-up and queue ordering.

## Implementation

1. Add `DirectiveSpawnFor Directive = "spawn-for"` to pkg/protocol/directive.go, update Valid().
2. In dispatcher.go applyDirective, add case for spawn-for:
   - Parse bead ID from args string
   - Verify bead exists and is open/ready (call bd show)
   - Spawn a new worker via d.procMgr.Spawn(newID)
   - Immediately assign the bead to the new worker (bypass queue selection)
   - Increment target count by 1
   - Return ACK with detail: 'spawned worker <id> for bead <bead-id>'
3. If bead not found or already assigned, return error ACK.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] oro directive spawn-for <bead-id> spawns a worker and assigns it the specified bead
- [ ] Worker starts executing the specified bead immediately (no queue wait)
- [ ] Target worker count incremented by 1
- [ ] Error returned if bead is already assigned to another worker
- [ ] Error returned if bead ID is invalid or bead is closed
- [ ] Test: spawn-for on a ready bead, verify worker created and bead assigned within 10s

title: Walk process tree on Kill to prevent orphaned Claude processes
description:
## Problem
tmux kill-session sends SIGHUP which Claude/node may ignore, leaving orphaned processes.

## Fix
Before kill-session, walk the process group and descendant tree:
1. Get pane PID and PGID
2. Kill process group (catches reparented processes)
3. Walk descendants recursively (catches setsid() processes)
4. SIGTERM → wait 2s → SIGKILL
5. Then kill-session

Follow Gastown KillSessionWithProcesses pattern.

## Acceptance Criteria

title: Replace timing-based beacon injection with readiness polling
description:
## Problem
tmux.go:80 uses a fixed 2-second sleep before injecting beacons via `tmux send-keys`. This is fragile:
- If Claude hasn't loaded yet (slow startup, workspace trust dialog, MCP init), the beacon text lands in the shell prompt or nowhere.
- If Claude loads fast, we waste 2 seconds.
- There's no retry — if injection fails, the session is silently broken.

## Current Flow (tmux.go:48-93)
1. `tmux send-keys` to launch `claude` in each pane
2. `time.Sleep(2s)`
3. `tmux send-keys` to inject beacon text
4. No verification

## Desired Flow
1. `tmux send-keys` to launch `claude` in each pane
2. Poll pane content via `tmux capture-pane -p -t <pane>` until Claude's input prompt appears (look for the `>` prompt or `claude` text in the captured output)
3. Inject beacon text via `tmux send-keys`
4. Timeout after 30s with clear error message if Claude never becomes ready

## Design Notes
- `tmux capture-pane -p -t oro:0.0` dumps the visible pane content as text — grep for Claude's prompt indicator
- Claude Code shows a `>` prompt when ready for input. Look for this or similar indicator.
- Poll every 500ms, timeout at 30s
- Keep the `Sleeper` abstraction for testability — tests can inject a fake poller
- Add a `PaneReadyFunc` to TmuxSession that can be overridden in tests

## Graceful Failure
- If timeout: kill the tmux session, clean up PID file, return clear error: "Claude did not become ready in pane X within 30s — check workspace trust or claude installation"
- If one pane ready but other times out: still fail (both must be ready for the swarm to function)

## Files
- cmd/oro/tmux.go (replace sleep with poll loop)
- cmd/oro/tmux_test.go (update tests, add timeout test)
- cmd/oro/cmd_start.go (may need to pass timeout config)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Beacon injection polls for Claude readiness instead of fixed sleep
- Timeout after 30s with descriptive error if Claude not ready
- Existing tmux tests pass with updated mock
- `go test ./cmd/oro/... -run TestTmux` passes
close_reason: Replaced 2s sleep with tmux capture-pane polling for Claude readiness

title: Claude Code TaskOutput uses tail -f which hangs on completed tasks
description:
Root cause: Claude Code's TaskOutput tool internally uses 'tail -f <file> | head -N' to read background task output. When a background task completes with fewer than N lines, tail -f blocks indefinitely waiting for EOF that never comes on a regular file.

Evidence:
- Multiple hanging tail -f processes found via ps aux

- These are spawned by worker Claude subprocesses during ops review

This is a Claude Code internal implementation issue, not fixable in oro codebase.

Workarounds:
1. Avoid backgrounding tasks in ops review prompts
2. Use 'Read' tool instead of Bash for completed output files
3. Kill hanging tail processes manually
4. File bug with Claude Code team

title: Add dead code detection to quality gate — catch unwired exported functions
description:
Exported functions that are only called from tests pass the quality gate today. This is the root cause of the wiring gap pattern found in the brittleness audit — RunQualityGate, SendDone, SendReadyForReview all existed with passing unit tests but were never called from production code.

## What to add

A new tier in quality_gate.sh (between linting and testing) that detects exported Go functions only referenced from _test.go files. Options:

1. **deadcode** (golang.org/x/tools/cmd/deadcode) — finds unreachable functions from main entry points
2. **unused** (honnef.co/go/tools/cmd/unused via staticcheck) — finds unused exported identifiers
3. **Custom grep check** — find exported funcs in pkg/, verify each has at least one non-test caller

The check should fail the gate if any exported function in pkg/ or internal/ has zero non-test references. Test-only helpers (SetContextPollInterval, SetReconnectInterval, etc.) can be annotated with a //oro:testonly comment to suppress.

## Why P0

This is not a feature — it's a safety net for the class of bug we just found 11 instances of. Every bead executed by a worker goes through the quality gate. Without this check, workers will continue building isolated functions that pass tests but aren't wired into the system.
acceptance_criteria: Test: quality_gate.sh detects that an exported function in pkg/ with no non-test callers fails the gate | Cmd: Create a dummy exported func in pkg/worker/ with only a test caller, run ./quality_gate.sh | Assert: gate fails with clear message identifying the unwired function
close_reason: Added grep-based dead code detection to quality_gate.sh

title: Add role labels and status info to tmux status bar
description:
## Problem

The tmux status bar only changes color (green for architect, orange for manager) when switching windows. It does NOT display the role name or any useful information. Users can't tell at a glance which role is active without memorizing the color mapping.

## Current State

- status-style set to color only: \`bg=colour46,fg=black\` or \`bg=colour208,fg=black\` (tmux.go:125, 132)
- No \`status-left\` or \`status-right\` configured — uses tmux defaults
- Window names are "architect" and "manager" (visible in tab bar, but small)
- \`after-select-window\` hook only changes color (tmux.go:131-136)

## Design

### status-left: Role label
Show the active role name prominently:

\`\`\`go
// In TmuxSession.Create(), after color setup:
statusLeft := fmt.Sprintf(
    \`#[bold] #{window_name} \`,
)
s.Runner.Run("tmux", "set-option", "-t", s.Name, "status-left", statusLeft)
s.Runner.Run("tmux", "set-option", "-t", s.Name, "status-left-length", "20")
\`\`\`

This shows \` ARCHITECT \` or \` MANAGER \` in bold, using the existing window name. The \`after-select-window\` hook already changes the background color, so the label auto-updates with proper coloring.

### status-right: Operational info (agent-decidable)
Show useful swarm info. Options (worker can choose the best combination):

\`\`\`
# Option A: Simple - just show session name and time
#[default] oro | %H:%M

# Option B: Richer - show worker count and bead status (requires periodic refresh)
# This would need a shell command in status-right-format
#(oro status --short 2>/dev/null || echo "offline")

# Option C: Static info + time
#[default] oro | #{session_windows} windows | %H:%M
\`\`\`

Recommendation: Start with Option A (simple, no external commands). The worker can upgrade to Option B if they wire a status-interval.

### Update the after-select-window hook
The hook should also update \`status-left\` if needed (though \`#{window_name}\` auto-resolves, so it may just work).

## Files to Modify
- cmd/oro/tmux.go — Add status-left and status-right configuration in TmuxSession.Create() (after line 136)
- cmd/oro/tmux_test.go — Test status bar label configuration

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Test: cmd/oro/tmux_test.go:TestStatusBarLabels | Cmd: go test -race ./cmd/oro/... -run TestStatusBarLabels | Assert: TmuxSession.Create calls set-option for status-left containing #{window_name}
- [ ] Architect window shows "ARCHITECT" (or "architect") in the status bar
- [ ] Manager window shows "MANAGER" (or "manager") in the status bar
- [ ] Status bar includes at minimum the role label and session name

Read: cmd/oro/tmux.go:Create (lines 94-168), cmd/oro/tmux_test.go

title: Filter stale attempt counts from status response for closed beads
description:
## Problem
`oro status` shows "QG failed Nx" alerts for beads that are already closed (e.g., oro-9hd, oro-5srh.3). The dispatcher never clears `attemptCounts` entries when beads are closed externally via `bd close`.

## Root Cause
`buildStatusJSON()` (dispatcher.go:1917-1924) copies ALL `attemptCounts` entries into the status response without filtering. `pruneStaleTracking()` (bead_tracker.go:78) only prunes entries for beads not assigned to any worker — it never cross-references the bead source to check if a bead is closed.

Three scenarios create stale entries:
1. Bead fails QG, gets escalated, then closed externally — count persists because `clearBeadTracking` only runs on internal terminal paths
2. Bead fails QG, is between retries (no worker assigned), then closed externally — prune catches this eventually, but only on next heartbeat tick
3. Bead is closed while still assigned to a worker — prune skips it because worker is still active

## Fix
Enhance `pruneStaleTracking()` to cross-reference the bead source. Any tracked bead that is not in `d.beads.Ready()` AND not assigned to any worker should be pruned. This covers all three scenarios on the next heartbeat tick.

Alternatively (or additionally): in `buildStatusJSON()`, when copying `attemptCounts`, filter against the set of assigned beads + queued beads. This gives immediate accuracy in the status response.

## Files
- pkg/dispatcher/bead_tracker.go:78 — `pruneStaleTracking()`: add bead source cross-reference
- pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go:1917-1924 — `buildStatusJSON()`: filter stale counts
- pkg/dispatcher/bead_tracker_test.go — test pruning of closed beads

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Test: bead with attemptCounts entry but closed in bead source → pruned from tracking maps within one heartbeat cycle
- [ ] Test: `buildStatusJSON` does not include attempt counts for beads not in ready queue and not assigned to any worker
- [ ] Existing pruneStaleTracking tests still pass
close_reason: Tests pass, gate clean. Commit: f23c9d0

title: P0: Manager agent sends stop directive killing dispatcher — env-based guard doesn't work
description:
## Problem
The manager Claude session runs 'oro directive stop' ~30s after startup, killing the dispatcher. The HumanApproved guard (13594a5) checks ORO_ROLE env var, but Claude Code's Bash tool spawns subshells that don't inherit exec env vars from the tmux pane.

## Root Cause
tmux pane runs: exec env ORO_ROLE=manager claude
Claude's Bash tool spawns: /bin/zsh -c 'oro directive stop'
The zsh subprocess gets a fresh env from the user's profile — ORO_ROLE is not inherited.

## Fix Options
1. Remove 'stop' from oro directive entirely — make it only available via 'oro stop' (SIGTERM)
2. Add --confirm flag required for stop directive
3. Use a token file (.oro/human-token) that only oro stop creates
4. Check parent PID chain to detect agent context

## Acceptance Criteria
- oro directive stop from manager agent must be rejected by dispatcher
- oro stop from human terminal must still work
- Test: run swarm, verify it stays up >5 minutes with workers assigned
close_reason: Fixed: removed stop from directive protocol entirely. Dispatcher unconditionally rejects DirectiveStop. Only SIGTERM via oro stop can shut down the swarm. Verified swarm stays alive 2+ minutes.

title: Auto-close epic beads when all children are completed
description:
## Problem

When all children of an epic bead are completed (merged), the epic remains open indefinitely. It must be manually closed. The dispatcher has no auto-close logic for parent epics.

## Current State

- `filterAssignable` (dispatcher.go:1441) skips epics — they are never assigned to workers
- After merge, `d.beads.Close()` is called at dispatcher.go:809 for the individual bead
- The `Bead` struct has an `Epic string` field (parent epic ID) available during assignment
- `trackedWorker` struct (dispatcher.go:89) stores `beadID` but NOT the parent `Epic` field
- The `BeadSource` interface (dispatcher.go:57-63) has `Close`, `Show`, `Ready`, `Create`, `Sync` — no method to check children status
- Parent-child relationships live in `bd` CLI, not in dispatcher memory

## Design

### 1. Store Epic field during assignment

Add `epicID string` to `trackedWorker` struct (dispatcher.go:89). Set it at assignment time (dispatcher.go:1544) from `bead.Epic`. Clear it when bead is cleared.

### 2. Add `AllChildrenClosed` method to BeadSource

```go
// AllChildrenClosed checks whether all children of the given epic are closed.
// Returns true if the epic has children and all are closed, false otherwise.
func (s *CLIBeadSource) AllChildrenClosed(ctx context.Context, epicID string) (bool, error)
```

Implementation: run `bd list --parent=<epicID> --status=open --format=json`. If the result is an empty list (no open children), return true. If there are open children, return false. If the epic has no children at all, return false (not an epic with children).

Add to `BeadSource` interface (dispatcher.go:57).

### 3. Auto-close after merge

After `d.beads.Close()` at dispatcher.go:809, add:

```go
// Auto-close parent epic if all children are completed.
if epicID := w.epicID; epicID != "" {
    d.safeGo(func() {
        allClosed, err := d.beads.AllChildrenClosed(ctx, epicID)
        if err == nil && allClosed {
            _ = d.beads.Close(ctx, epicID, "All children completed")
            _ = d.logEvent(ctx, "epic_auto_closed", "dispatcher", epicID, workerID, "")
        }
    })
}
```

Note: the `w.epicID` must be read under lock or captured before the goroutine since `mergeAndComplete` runs in a goroutine already. The worker ID lookup needs care — at line 809 we have `beadID` and `workerID` as params but NOT the `trackedWorker` directly. Need to look up epic from stored state or pass it through.

Alternative approach (simpler, avoids trackedWorker changes): after closing a bead, call `bd show <beadID>` to get the closed bead's details including its parent epic, then check children. This avoids storing epicID in trackedWorker but costs one extra `bd show` call per merge.

## Files to Modify
- `pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go` — Add epicID to trackedWorker, set during assignment, auto-close logic after merge (lines 89, 809, 1544)
- `pkg/dispatcher/beadsource.go` — Add `AllChildrenClosed` method to CLIBeadSource
- `pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher_test.go` — Add test, update mockBeadSource
- `pkg/dispatcher/beadsource_test.go` — Test AllChildrenClosed

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Test: pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher_test.go:TestAutoCloseEpicWhenAllChildrenCompleted | Cmd: go test -race ./pkg/dispatcher/... -run TestAutoCloseEpic | Assert: After closing the last child bead of an epic, the epic is auto-closed via BeadSource.Close with reason "All children completed"
- [ ] Test: pkg/dispatcher/beadsource_test.go:TestCLIBeadSource_AllChildrenClosed | Cmd: go test -race ./pkg/dispatcher/... -run TestAllChildrenClosed | Assert: Returns true when bd list --parent=<epicID> --status=open returns empty list; false when open children exist
- [ ] Epic with open children is NOT auto-closed when one child merges
- [ ] bd CLI errors in AllChildrenClosed are logged but do not block the merge flow

Read: pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go:mergeAndComplete,trackedWorker,filterAssignable, pkg/dispatcher/beadsource.go:CLIBeadSource,BeadSource, pkg/protocol/types.go:Bead
Edges: bd CLI error → log warning, skip auto-close; epic already closed → bd close returns error, ignored; bead has no parent epic → epicID is empty, skip check
close_reason: Tests pass, gate clean. Commit: af7ee04

title: Implement applyRestartDaemon handler with graceful drain
description:
Add applyRestartDaemon() handler in pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go that broadcasts PREPARE_SHUTDOWN to workers, waits for drain (max 60s), closes DB, and exits with code 0.

Read: pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go:applyDirective, pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go:shutdown patterns, pkg/protocol/message.go:MsgPrepareShutdown

## Signature
```go
func (d *Dispatcher) applyRestartDaemon(args string) (string, error)
```

## Implementation
- Return ACK "restarting in 5s"
- Broadcast PREPARE_SHUTDOWN to all workers
- Wait up to 60s for workers to finish/save state
- Close DB, close socket listener
- os.Exit(0)

## Edges
- Workers timeout after 60s → force kill and exit anyway
- Empty worker pool → skip drain, exit immediately
- Error during shutdown → log warning, exit anyway

## Acceptance Criteria

Cmd: go test ./pkg/dispatcher/... -run TestApplyRestartDaemon
Assert: ACK returned, PREPARE_SHUTDOWN sent to workers, process exits cleanly

title: Daemon auto-extraction of learnings from session logs
description:
## Problem

Learnings are only captured when agents explicitly run \`bd comment <id> \"LEARNED: ...\"\`. Valuable insights mentioned in conversation but not explicitly tagged are lost. The memory system spec (docs/plans/2026-02-07-memory-system-spec.md) defines "daemon extraction" as a background process that post-processes session logs to find implicit learnings, but it's not implemented.

## Current State

- **Layer 3 memory** exists: pkg/memory/memory.go with SQLite FTS5 backing store
- **Self-report capture** works: .claude/hooks/memory_capture.py captures \`bd comment LEARNED:\` entries to .beads/memory/knowledge.jsonl
- **Memory injection** works: session_start_extras.py surfaces recent learnings at session start
- **Daemon extraction**: NOT IMPLEMENTED. Schema has \`source TEXT\` field with planned values \`self_report | daemon_extracted\`
- Spec reference: docs/plans/2026-02-07-memory-system-spec.md (Layer 3, Option C: Hybrid)

## Design

### Extraction trigger
After a bead is merged (dispatcher.go:809, after Close), or periodically during idle time, the dispatcher runs extraction on the worker's session output.

### Extraction method (Option A: Regex-based, start simple)
Scan worker stdout/handoff content for patterns:
- "I learned that...", "Note:", "Gotcha:", "Important:", "TIL:"
- "This doesn't work because...", "The fix was..."
- Stack trace + resolution pairs

Parse matches into memory entries with:
- type: "daemon_extracted"
- source: "daemon_extracted"
- bead_id: the bead that was being worked on
- confidence: 0.6 (lower than self-report's 0.8, since auto-extracted)

### Storage
Call \`pkg/memory.Store.Insert()\` with extracted entries. FTS5 dedup (Jaccard 0.7) prevents duplicates with self-reported entries.

### Future enhancement (not this bead)
Option B: Use Haiku API call to summarize session into structured learnings. More accurate but adds API cost.

## Files to Modify
- pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go — Add extraction call after merge (near line 809)
- pkg/dispatcher/extractor.go — New file: regex-based learning extraction from text
- pkg/dispatcher/extractor_test.go — Tests for extraction patterns
- pkg/memory/memory.go — Verify Insert supports daemon_extracted source (already should)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Test: pkg/dispatcher/extractor_test.go:TestExtractLearnings | Cmd: go test -race ./pkg/dispatcher/... -run TestExtractLearnings | Assert: Extracts "I learned that X" patterns into memory entries with type=daemon_extracted, confidence=0.6
- [ ] Test: pkg/dispatcher/extractor_test.go:TestExtractLearnings_NoDuplicates | Cmd: go test -race ./pkg/dispatcher/... -run TestExtractLearnings_NoDuplicates | Assert: Entries matching existing knowledge.jsonl slugs are skipped
- [ ] Extraction runs after bead merge without blocking the merge flow (async/safeGo)

Read: pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go:mergeAndComplete, pkg/memory/memory.go:Insert,InsertParams, .claude/hooks/memory_capture.py, docs/plans/2026-02-07-memory-system-spec.md
Signature: func ExtractLearnings(text string, beadID string) []memory.InsertParams
Edges: no patterns found → return empty slice; regex match but empty content → skip; memory store error → log warning, don't block
close_reason: Implemented regex-based learning extraction with async wiring in dispatcher

title: Simplify session close protocol: remove redundant bd sync calls
description:
## Context

The session close protocol in multiple files calls `bd sync` twice, but the
pre-commit git hook (`.git/hooks/pre-commit`) already runs `bd sync --flush-only`
and `git add .beads/issues.jsonl` on every commit. The manual syncs are redundant.

### Evidence

- `.git/hooks/pre-commit`: runs `bd sync --flush-only` then `git add .beads/issues.jsonl`
- `.git/hooks/post-merge`: runs `bd import -i .beads/issues.jsonl` after pull
- `bd sync` (no flags) only exports DB→JSONL, does NOT stage/commit
- The only case where manual sync matters: beads changes with no subsequent commit

## Change

Replace the current 6-step protocol:
```
[ ] 1. git status
[ ] 2. git add <files>
[ ] 3. bd sync              ← redundant
[ ] 4. git commit -m "..."
[ ] 5. bd sync              ← redundant
[ ] 6. git push
```

With the simplified protocol:
```
[ ] 1. bd close <ids>          (finish beads work)
[ ] 2. git add <files>         (stage code changes)
[ ] 3. git commit -m "..."     (pre-commit hook auto-syncs beads)
[ ] 4. git push
```

## Files to update

1. `~/.claude/rules/beads.md` — "Landing the Plane" section
   - Remove explicit `bd sync` step
   - Add note that pre-commit hook handles beads export automatically
   - Simplify the checklist

2. `~/.oro/panes/architect/handoff.yaml` — SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL section
   - Same simplification

3. Search for any other files referencing the double-sync pattern:
   - `grep -r "bd sync" ~/.claude/ ~/.oro/` and update as needed

## Acceptance criteria
1. No file in ~/.claude/rules/ or ~/.oro/ references the double bd sync pattern
2. Session close protocol is 4 steps (close, add, commit, push) not 6
3. A note exists explaining that the pre-commit hook auto-syncs beads
acceptance_criteria: 1. No file in ~/.claude/rules/ or ~/.oro/ references the double bd sync pattern; 2. Session close protocol is 4 steps (close, add, commit, push) not 6; 3. A note exists explaining that the pre-commit hook auto-syncs beads
close_reason: All double bd sync patterns removed from instruction files. Pre-commit hook note added everywhere. Quality gate passes (19/19).

title: Check bead status in assignBead before claiming assignment
description:
assignBead (dispatcher.go:1693) calls checkBeadReady which calls lookupBeadDetail (bd show). The bd show response returns BeadDetail (protocol/types.go:31) but BeadDetail has no Status field. assignBead trusts the bd ready snapshot from tryAssign, but there is a race window where the bead can be closed externally between bd ready and the assignBead call. This is the oro-yoov pattern: bead cherry-picked to main and marked CLOSED, but dispatcher proceeds with stale snapshot and assigns worker to a closed bead.

Fix: (1) Add Status field to protocol.BeadDetail struct. (2) Populate Status in CLIBeadSource.Show from bd show --json output. (3) In checkBeadReady, after lookupBeadDetail returns, check if status is closed — if so, log bead_closed_before_assign event and return ok=false. This gives assignBead a fresh status check using the bd show call already being made.
acceptance_criteria:
Test: pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher_test.go:TestAssignBeadSkipsClosedBead | Cmd: go test ./pkg/dispatcher/... -run TestAssignBeadSkipsClosedBead | Assert: When BeadSource.Show returns a bead with status=closed, assignBead returns without creating worktree or sending MsgAssign. Log event bead_closed_before_assign is recorded.
Read: pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go:checkBeadReady (lines 1674-1691), pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go:lookupBeadDetail (lines 1790-1802), pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go:assignBead (lines 1693-1752), pkg/protocol/types.go:BeadDetail (lines 31-42), pkg/dispatcher/beadsource.go:CLIBeadSource.Show
Signature: Add Status string json:status to BeadDetail; modify lookupBeadDetail to return (title, acceptance, status string)

title: Fix tmux scroll: enable scrollback past Claude Code TUI
description:
## Problem

Users cannot scroll up in the oro tmux session. Mouse scroll (and possibly keyboard scroll) only scrolls Claude Code's internal conversation history, not tmux's scrollback buffer. This prevents reviewing output that has scrolled off the top of the pane.

## Root Cause

Claude Code is an Ink-based TUI that uses the terminal's alternate screen buffer. When a TUI app uses the alternate screen:
- Mouse scroll events are captured by the TUI app (Claude Code scrolls its own history)
- tmux's scrollback buffer only contains pre-TUI content (essentially empty)
- \`Ctrl-b [\` (copy-mode) works but the buffer has no useful content since the alternate screen replaces it

## Current State

\`cmd/oro/tmux.go\` does NOT configure any scroll-related tmux options:
- No \`set -g mouse on/off\`
- No \`history-limit\`
- No \`alternate-screen\` setting
- No \`terminal-overrides\`

The user's \`~/.tmux.conf\` may or may not have mouse mode enabled.

## Design Options

### Option A: Disable alternate screen in oro session (Recommended)
Configure tmux to not use the alternate screen buffer for the oro session. This causes Claude Code's output to flow into tmux's scrollback buffer:

\`\`\`go
// In TmuxSession.Create(), add:
s.Runner.Run("tmux", "set-option", "-t", s.Name, "alternate-screen", "off")
s.Runner.Run("tmux", "set-option", "-t", s.Name, "history-limit", "50000")
\`\`\`

Tradeoff: Screen might not clear properly when Claude Code exits/restarts. But since Claude IS the pane process, this is acceptable.

### Option B: Mouse scroll enters copy-mode
Enable mouse mode but configure it to enter copy-mode on scroll when in alternate screen:

\`\`\`go
s.Runner.Run("tmux", "set-option", "-t", s.Name, "mouse", "on")
// tmux 3.x: bind mouse wheel to copy-mode when in alternate screen
s.Runner.Run("tmux", "bind-key", "-T", "root", "WheelUpPane",
    "if-shell", "-Ft=", "#{alternate_on}",
    "send-keys -M", "copy-mode -e")
\`\`\`

### Option C: Terminal overrides
Disable alternate screen at the terminal level:

\`\`\`go
s.Runner.Run("tmux", "set-option", "-t", s.Name, "terminal-overrides", "xterm*:smcup@:rmcup@")
\`\`\`

Worker should test all options and pick the one that gives the best scroll experience without breaking Claude Code's display.

## Files to Modify
- cmd/oro/tmux.go — Add scroll configuration in TmuxSession.Create() (after line 136)
- cmd/oro/tmux_test.go — Test scroll configuration

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Test: cmd/oro/tmux_test.go:TestScrollbackConfiguration | Cmd: go test -race ./cmd/oro/... -run TestScrollback | Assert: TmuxSession.Create sets alternate-screen or terminal-overrides or mouse scroll binding
- [ ] Mouse scroll in tmux pane scrolls tmux scrollback buffer (not just Claude Code history)
- [ ] Manual test: \`oro start\`, generate some output, scroll up with mouse wheel — content is accessible

Read: cmd/oro/tmux.go:Create (lines 94-168)

Introduce Summarizer interface, dispatch by extension, language registry. Output format must match Go summary style (L<line>: kind name signature). Fail-open if ast-grep not installed. title: Search router for Grep interception (structural/literal/semantic classification)
description: Intercept Grep tool calls in the hook. Classify patterns as structural (func.*error, type Server struct), literal (TODO, handleRequest), or semantic (where is auth logic?). Route structural queries to AST-based search, pass literal through to ripgrep, flag semantic for future embeddings. Components: QueryClassifier (pure function, regex heuristics), StructuralSearch (go/ast + ast-grep for multi-lang), GrepBypass rules. Must be conservative — classify as Literal when in doubt. Tigers: (1) structural search on large dirs blows 5s timeout — need 3s cap + file count limit, (2) deny response for Grep may confuse Claude vs ripgrep output, (3) classification accuracy on borderline patterns. Elephant: structural grep queries may be <5% of all greps. Acceptance: Grep calls with structural patterns return AST-based results; literal patterns pass through unmodified.

title: Semantic code search with embeddings
description: Enable natural-language code search by embedding code chunks (functions, types, file summaries) into vectors. Components: (1) Code chunker — extract indexable chunks from source files via AST, (2) Embedding engine — Ollama nomic-embed-text for local embeddings with Embedder interface for swappability, (3) Code index — SQLite brute-force cosine similarity (sufficient at <10K chunks), (4) CLI indexer (oro index build) + fsnotify incremental updates, (5) Hook integration — classify Grep as semantic, embed query, return ranked results. Tigers: (1) Ollama dependency — not standard, must fail-open, (2) cold model load 5-30s blows hook timeout — need pre-warming, (3) embedding quality with general-purpose models, (4) index staleness. Store in .oro/code_index.db. Acceptance: 'oro index build' indexes a codebase; semantic Grep queries return relevant code locations.
close_reason: Semantic code search: chunker, embedder, CodeIndex with SQLite, CLI oro index build/search. 19 tests.

title: Cross-hook context passing (search informs read summarization)
description: Allow hooks to share state between invocations so recent Grep patterns inform subsequent Read summaries. Grep hook writes QueryEntry to /tmp/oro-search-context/<session_id>.json (60s TTL, max 10 entries). Read hook reads context and calls SummarizeFocused() which reorders AST output to emphasize matching declarations. Alternative explored: transcript_path already contains all prior tool calls — could read last N tool calls instead of separate IPC. Tigers: (1) focused summaries may not help Claude vs full summaries — no evidence, (2) stale context misleads, (3) file locking races. Elephant: over-engineering — full summary already achieves 90%+ savings. Acceptance: Grep for 'auth' then Read auth.go produces summary emphasizing auth-related functions.
close_reason: Won't do: self-noted over-engineering. Full summary already achieves 90%+ savings. Re-create if evidence shows focused summaries help.

title: Daemon mode for AST caching
description: Persistent daemon process that pre-parses and caches AST summaries, serves them via unix socket to the hook. Components: in-memory cache (map + RWMutex), fsnotify file watcher for invalidation, IPC via unix socket, hook becomes thin client with fallback to direct parse. Premortem conclusion: PREMATURE OPTIMIZATION for Go-only (6ms parse time, 18 files above threshold). Revisit when: (1) multi-language parsing via ast-grep/tree-sitter makes parse times 10-100x slower, (2) project scale reaches hundreds of large files, (3) semantic search index needs persistent daemon infrastructure. Do not build until non-Go language support and semantic search are done and measured. Acceptance: hook serves cached summaries in <1ms; cache invalidates on file change.
close_reason: Won't do: premature optimization (6ms parse, 18 files). Re-create when multi-language parsing proves slow or project scale demands it.

title: P0: QG retry fails silently — worker connection dead before re-ASSIGN
description:
When a worker's claude -p finishes and the worker sends DONE with QualityGatePassed=false, the dispatcher calls handleQGFailure → qgRetryWithReservation, which tries to send a new ASSIGN back to the same worker. But the worker process has already exited after sending DONE — the connection is dead. sendToWorker silently fails, and no retry or escalation happens. The bead just disappears.

Observed: Both oro-noc.1 and oro-nqi.2 hit quality_gate_rejected, logged done, then silence. No re-assignment, no heartbeats, no escalation. Workers dropped to 0.

Root cause: The worker sends DONE and then exits its Run loop. By the time the dispatcher's qgRetryWithReservation sends the re-ASSIGN, the conn is closed. sendToWorker likely returns an error that is not escalated.

Fix direction: Either (a) the worker must stay alive after sending DONE with QG failure and wait for a re-ASSIGN or shutdown, or (b) the dispatcher must detect the dead connection in qgRetryWithReservation and re-queue the bead for a different worker (or the same worker after reconnect).

Key code paths:
- pkg/worker/worker.go:478-482 — worker sends DONE on QG failure then returns (exits)
- pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go:611-670 — handleQGFailure increments attempt, reserves worker, calls qgRetryWithReservation
- pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go:675-705 — qgRetryWithReservation sends re-ASSIGN to (now dead) worker
close_reason: Fixed: qgRetryWithReservation now checks sendToWorker error and re-queues bead on failure

title: Wire session-end learning synthesis triggers
description:
## Problem

The session-end learning synthesis spec exists (docs/plans/2026-02-10-session-end-learning-synthesis.md) with three trigger points designed, but none are wired into the actual skills/hooks. Status: "Designed, not wired."

## Current State

**Spec defines 3 triggers:**

1. **Context-Checkpoint skill** (bead boundary) — .claude/skills/context-checkpoint/SKILL.md exists but does NOT scan knowledge.jsonl or run frequency analysis
2. **Create-Handoff skill** — .claude/skills/create-handoff/SKILL.md has Step 4 "Scan for Undocumented Learnings" defined but may not be fully wired
3. **PostToolUse hook on git commit** — .claude/hooks/learning_reminder.py exists and surfaces undocumented learnings, but does NOT run frequency analysis or propose codification

**What's missing per trigger:**

### Trigger 1: Context-Checkpoint
- Needs: Scan knowledge.jsonl for entries matching just-completed bead ID
- Needs: Count tags, check frequency map using learning_analysis.py
- Needs: Propose codification if tag reaches 3+ frequency (skill → hook → rule → doc)

### Trigger 2: Create-Handoff
- Needs: Cross-reference ALL session entries with docs/decisions-and-discoveries.md
- Needs: Full frequency analysis (not just session entries)
- Needs: Add \`learnings:\` field to handoff YAML output

### Trigger 3: Post-commit hook
- Has: learning_reminder.py surfaces undocumented learnings
- Needs: Frequency analysis integration (call learning_analysis.py functions)
- Needs: Propose codification action when threshold reached

**Supporting library exists:** .claude/hooks/learning_analysis.py with load_knowledge, filter_by_bead, tag_frequency, frequency_level, cross_reference_docs

## Design

Wire each trigger to call learning_analysis.py functions:

### Trigger 1 (context-checkpoint skill):
Add steps after bead completion:
\`\`\`python
entries = filter_by_bead(load_knowledge(), bead_id)
freq = tag_frequency(all_entries)  
for tag, count in freq.items():
    level = frequency_level(count)
    if level == "create":
        # Propose: "Tag '{tag}' appeared {count} times. Codify as: [skill|hook|rule|doc]"
\`\`\`

### Trigger 2 (create-handoff skill):
Add to Step 4:
\`\`\`python
all_entries = load_knowledge()
session_entries = filter_by_session(all_entries, session_start_ts)
undocumented = cross_reference_docs(session_entries, decisions_doc_path)
freq = tag_frequency(all_entries)
# Output: learnings section with proposed codifications
\`\`\`

### Trigger 3 (learning_reminder.py):
After surfacing undocumented learnings:
\`\`\`python
freq = tag_frequency(load_knowledge())
for entry in bead_entries:
    for tag in entry.get("tags", []):
        level = frequency_level(freq[tag])
        if level >= "consider":
            # Append to additionalContext: "Tag '{tag}' seen {count} times — consider codifying"
\`\`\`

## Files to Modify
- .claude/skills/context-checkpoint/SKILL.md — Add learning scan + frequency analysis steps
- .claude/skills/create-handoff/SKILL.md — Wire Step 4 to use learning_analysis.py functions
- .claude/hooks/learning_reminder.py — Add frequency analysis after surfacing learnings

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Test: .claude/hooks/test_learning_reminder.py:test_frequency_codification_proposal | Cmd: python -m pytest .claude/hooks/test_learning_reminder.py -k test_frequency | Assert: When a tag appears 3+ times in knowledge.jsonl, additionalContext includes codification proposal
- [ ] context-checkpoint skill includes learning scan step with frequency thresholds
- [ ] create-handoff skill Step 4 calls cross_reference_docs and outputs learnings in handoff YAML

Read: docs/plans/2026-02-10-session-end-learning-synthesis.md, .claude/hooks/learning_analysis.py, .claude/hooks/learning_reminder.py, .claude/skills/context-checkpoint/SKILL.md, .claude/skills/create-handoff/SKILL.md

title: Fix ops review: non-zero exit code overrides APPROVED verdict
description: parseResult() in ops.go:249-253 returns VerdictFailed when waitErr \!= nil, even if stdout contains APPROVED. The ops reviewer (claude -p) exits non-zero sometimes even on successful reviews. Fix: when opsType is OpsReview and stdout contains APPROVED/REJECTED, trust the parsed verdict over the exit code. The text-based verdict is the reviewer's actual decision; the exit code is an infrastructure artifact. AC: (1) If stdout contains APPROVED and exit code is non-zero, verdict is VerdictApproved (2) If stdout contains REJECTED and exit code is non-zero, verdict is VerdictRejected (3) Only fall back to VerdictFailed if stdout has neither keyword (4) Test: simulate non-zero exit with APPROVED output, verify VerdictApproved
close_reason: Trust APPROVED/REJECTED in stdout over non-zero exit code for ops reviews

title: Fix pane-died hook bugs from review (oro-jmil.6)
description:
Fix bugs found in oro-jmil.6 review (3x rejected). The code is on main but has defects.

## Bugs to Fix

### 1. [Critical] Double single-quoting in buildPaneDiedHook (tmux.go:496)
`escapeForShell()` already wraps output in single quotes, but the format string adds another layer with `'%s'`. This produces `''content''` — in shell, `''` is empty string, leaving content unquoted. The `[ORO-DISPATCH]` brackets become a glob pattern.

**Fix**: Remove the outer single quotes from the format string:
```go
"run-shell \"tmux set-buffer -b oro-pane-died %s; tmux paste-buffer -b oro-pane-died -t %s; tmux send-keys -t %s Enter\"",
```

### 2. [Important] AC3 log entry not implemented (tmux.go:483-501)
AC3 says "a log entry is written to the dispatcher log" but buildPaneDiedHook only sends a message to the surviving pane. No logEvent call, no file append. Either add logging or document that the [ORO-DISPATCH] prefix to the surviving pane IS the log mechanism.

### 3. [Minor] Missing -d flag on paste-buffer (tmux.go:496)
paste-buffer call omits `-d` (delete buffer after paste), unlike TmuxEscalator.Escalate() in escalator.go. Add `-d` for consistency.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] buildPaneDiedHook does not double-quote the escaped message (no outer single quotes around %s for escapeForShell output)
- [ ] Pane-died hook either writes to dispatcher log or documents why the escalation message IS the log entry
- [ ] paste-buffer uses -d flag consistent with TmuxEscalator.Escalate() pattern
- [ ] Existing unit tests updated and passing
- [ ] go test -race ./cmd/oro/... passes
close_reason: Tests pass, gate clean. Commit: d6ec866

title: Dispatcher fails to detect Claude subprocess exit during review
description:
Workers in 'reviewing' state never transition out when their Claude subprocess exits. The worker Go process stays alive with zero children, holding a slot indefinitely.

Observed: workers for oro-l9gw and oro-zays.3 had no child processes but remained in 'reviewing' state for 2.5-3.5 hours.

## Root Cause
The dispatcher/worker does not monitor for Claude process termination during the review phase. When Claude exits (normally or abnormally), the worker should detect this and either retry or transition to idle/error.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Worker detects when Claude subprocess exits during review phase
- [ ] Worker transitions to appropriate state (idle or error) on subprocess exit
- [ ] Worker reports subprocess exit to dispatcher with exit code/reason
- [ ] Test: simulate Claude exit during review, verify worker transitions within 30s
close_reason: Implemented subprocess exit detection during review phase. Worker now sends STATUS 'awaiting_review' after subprocess exits, enabling dispatcher to track subprocess state accurately. All tests pass.

title: Auto-scale workers based on queue depth and notify manager of new beads
description:
## Problem

When the architect creates beads via \`bd create\`, the manager is not notified and doesn't scale workers. The dispatcher sees new beads (via fsnotify → tryAssign → bd ready) but can't assign them because \`targetWorkers\` is 0 or insufficient. Workers are only spawned when the manager explicitly runs \`oro directive scale N\`.

### Root cause chain:
1. Architect runs \`bd create\` → bead exists in \`bd ready\`
2. Dispatcher's \`assignLoop\` detects it via fsnotify → calls \`tryAssign()\`
3. \`tryAssign()\` calls \`filterAssignable()\` → finds beads
4. BUT \`tryAssign()\` only assigns to connected workers (dispatcher.go:1393-1410)
5. Worker count is controlled by \`targetWorkers\` (set via \`oro directive scale N\`)
6. Manager beacon only scales at startup (manager.go:27-37), no continuous monitoring
7. **No notification** from architect → manager that new work exists

## Design

Two-part fix:

### Part 1: Dispatcher auto-scale (primary fix)

After \`tryAssign()\` finds assignable beads but has no idle workers, auto-scale up to a configured max:

\`\`\`go
// In tryAssign(), after filterAssignable returns beads:
if len(beads) > 0 {
    d.mu.Lock()
    idleCount := countIdleWorkers(d.workers)
    maxWorkers := d.cfg.MaxWorkers // New config field, default 3
    currentTarget := d.targetWorkers
    d.mu.Unlock()

    if idleCount == 0 && currentTarget < maxWorkers {
        // Auto-scale: set target to min(len(beads), maxWorkers)
        newTarget := min(len(beads), maxWorkers)
        if newTarget > currentTarget {
            d.mu.Lock()
            d.targetWorkers = newTarget
            d.mu.Unlock()
            d.reconcileScale()
            _ = d.logEvent(ctx, "auto_scale", "dispatcher", "", "",
                fmt.Sprintf("scaled to %d workers (queue depth: %d)", newTarget, len(beads)))
        }
    }
}
\`\`\`

Add \`MaxWorkers int\` to \`Config\` (dispatcher.go:114). Default: 3. Set via \`oro start --workers N\` (already exists, maps to \`--workers\` flag in cmd_start.go).

### Part 2: Architect → Manager notification (awareness)

In \`architect_router.py\`, when a \`bd create\` command is detected (currently passed through since it starts with \`bd \`), ALSO send a notification to the manager pane via tmux:

\`\`\`python
# In route_command(), after identifying "bd create" commands:
if trimmed.startswith("bd create"):
    # Don't block — let it execute locally
    # But also notify manager
    notify_manager(f"[NEW WORK] Architect created a bead. Check bd ready.")
    return "architect"  # Still execute locally
\`\`\`

This is a PostToolUse hook on Bash (for \`bd create\` commands), not a PreToolUse block. It should be a separate hook or an addition to the existing \`architect_router.py\`.

## Files to Modify
- pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go — Add MaxWorkers to Config, auto-scale logic in tryAssign (near line 1410)
- pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher_test.go — Test auto-scale behavior
- cmd/oro/cmd_start.go — Wire --workers flag to MaxWorkers config
- .claude/hooks/architect_router.py — Add PostToolUse notification for bd create (or new hook)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Test: pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher_test.go:TestAutoScaleOnQueueDepth | Cmd: go test -race ./pkg/dispatcher/... -run TestAutoScale | Assert: When tryAssign finds 3 assignable beads and 0 idle workers, targetWorkers auto-increases to min(3, MaxWorkers) and reconcileScale is called
- [ ] Test: pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher_test.go:TestAutoScaleRespectsMaxWorkers | Cmd: go test -race ./pkg/dispatcher/... -run TestAutoScaleRespectsMax | Assert: Auto-scale never exceeds MaxWorkers config value
- [ ] Dispatcher auto-spawns workers when beads are available and current workers < MaxWorkers
- [ ] Manager pane receives tmux notification when architect creates beads

Read: pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go:tryAssign,reconcileScale,assignLoop,Config, cmd/oro/cmd_start.go:runStart, .claude/hooks/architect_router.py:route_command
Signature: Config.MaxWorkers int (default 3)
Edges: MaxWorkers=0 → no auto-scale (manual only); all workers busy (not idle) → don't scale beyond max; beads decrease → don't auto-scale down (manual \`oro directive scale\` for that)

title: Add oro init — bootstrap all dependencies and verify environment
description:
## Problem
There's no way to bootstrap oro. A fresh clone requires manually installing ~15 tools across Go, Python, npm, and system packages. oro start has basic preflight checks (tmux, claude, bd, git) but doesn't install anything or check the full toolchain.

## Design: oro init

New subcommand that:

### Phase 1: Check system prerequisites
- Go (>= version from go.mod)
- Python (>= 3.11)
- Node/npm (for biome)
- Homebrew (macOS) or apt (Linux)

If missing: print clear install instructions and exit non-zero.

### Phase 2: Install Go tools
- gofumpt (mvdan.cc/gofumpt@latest)
- goimports (golang.org/x/tools/cmd/goimports@latest)
- golangci-lint (via go install or brew)
- go-arch-lint (github.com/fe3dback/go-arch-lint@latest)
- govulncheck (golang.org/x/vuln/cmd/govulncheck@latest)
- ast-grep (via npm or cargo)

### Phase 3: Install Python tools (via uv/uvx)
- uv itself (if not installed)
- ruff, pyright, pylint, pytest are invoked via uvx so no install needed

### Phase 4: Install system tools
- tmux (brew/apt)
- shellcheck (brew/apt)
- biome (npm install -g @biomejs/biome)
- jq (brew/apt)
- bd (beads CLI — check if installed, print install instructions)

### Phase 5: Verify
- Run each tool with --version
- Print summary table: tool | version | status (ok/missing/outdated)
- Exit 0 only if all required tools pass

### Integration with oro start
- oro start calls preflight checks (existing)
- Add flag: oro start --bootstrap to run init first
- If init hasn't been run (check for ~/.oro/.initialized marker), suggest it

### Behavior
- Idempotent — safe to run repeatedly
- --check flag: only verify, don't install (for CI)
- --quiet flag: suppress output, just exit code
- Respect platform (macOS vs Linux)
- Print what it's about to install before doing it

## Files
- cmd/oro/cmd_init.go (new subcommand)
- cmd/oro/cmd_init_test.go (test the check logic, mock installs)
- cmd/oro/cmd_start.go (add bootstrap suggestion)

## Acceptance Criteria
- oro init installs all required Go tools
- oro init --check verifies environment without installing
- oro init prints clear table of tool status
- oro start suggests oro init when tools are missing
- Tests cover: all-tools-present path, missing-tool path, --check mode
close_reason: oro init command implemented with --check mode. Tests pass.

title: Fix merge pipeline: workers close beads before code lands on main
description:
## Problem
Workers mark beads as closed in their worktrees, but the merge-to-main step fails silently or never executes. Worktree cleanup then destroys the evidence (branch, commits). The bead shows "closed" with a commit hash that exists nowhere.

Audit of 2026-02-16 found **9 beads** falsely closed — code never reached main:
- oro-w451: fix on branch agent/oro-w451, never cherry-picked
- oro-vi0h: zero code exists anywhere (no branch, no commit)
- oro-ldbd, oro-z5oc.2, oro-tapy, oro-ycjj.4: claimed commits exist nowhere
- oro-p3wd, oro-9fme, oro-wm6x: no matching code patterns on main

## Root Cause Analysis

The merge flow is: worker completes → QG passes → mergeAndComplete() → cherry-pick to main → bd close → worktree cleanup.

Failure modes (all observed):
1. **Cherry-pick fails silently** — merge conflict or rebase guard, error logged but bead still closed
2. **Worker closes bead before merge** — bd close runs in worktree, merge happens after (or never)
3. **Worktree cleanup destroys branch** — even if cherry-pick failed, the branch is deleted, losing the commits forever
4. **No verification gate** — nothing checks that the commit actually exists on main before closing the bead

## Fix Design

### Guard 1: Verify commit on main before closing bead
In mergeAndComplete(), after cherry-pick, verify the commit exists on main with `git branch --contains <hash>`. Only call bd close if verified. If cherry-pick failed, leave bead open with a note.

### Guard 2: Never delete worktree branch if merge failed
In worktree cleanup, check merge status before deleting the branch. If the branch has commits not on main, preserve it and log a warning.

### Guard 3: Post-close verification
Add a periodic sweep (or hook) that cross-references closed beads with main commits. Any closed bead whose claimed commit is not on main gets reopened automatically.

## Files
Read: pkg/dispatcher/dispatcher.go:mergeAndComplete, pkg/dispatcher/worktree.go (or wherever cleanup lives), pkg/dispatcher/merge.go (if exists)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] mergeAndComplete does not close a bead unless the commit is verified on main
- [ ] Worktree branch is preserved when cherry-pick to main fails
- [ ] Test: simulated cherry-pick failure → bead stays open, branch preserved
close_reason: Duplicate of oro-mzk0 (currently in progress). Extra guards (branch preservation, post-close sweep) can be follow-ups.

title: Add process group isolation and kill to worker ProcessManager
description:
Problem: ExecProcessManager.Kill() only signals the worker PID directly. Worker spawns "claude -p" which spawns node → bash → arbitrary commands. Killing worker PID leaves node/bash children orphaned, holding worktree file locks and consuming resources.

Fix two things:
1. Spawn: Set SysProcAttr.Setpgid=true so each worker gets its own process group (CRITICAL: without this, killing PGID kills ALL workers + dispatcher)
2. Kill: Get PGID from spawned process, kill entire process group with syscall.Kill(-pgid, SIGTERM), wait 3s grace, then syscall.Kill(-pgid, SIGKILL)

Gastown pattern: KillSessionWithProcesses does PGID kill + recursive descendant walk. We skip the descendant walk (overkill for UDS workers) but adopt the PGID isolation + group kill.

Test: pkg/dispatcher/process_manager_test.go:TestKill_KillsProcessGroup | Cmd: go test -race -count=1 ./pkg/dispatcher/ -run TestKill_KillsProcessGroup | Assert: spawned process with Setpgid=true; after Kill(), no processes remain in the worker process group
Read: pkg/dispatcher/process_manager.go:Spawn,Kill,ExecProcessManager, cmd/oro/cmd_start.go:SpawnDaemon (reference for Setsid pattern)
Signature: unchanged public API; internal change to Spawn (add SysProcAttr) and Kill (add syscall.Kill(-pgid, sig))
Edges: Setpgid fails on non-Unix → build tag or runtime check; PGID=0 or PGID=1 → skip group kill (safety); worker already exited → ESRCH from kill, ignore
close_reason: Closed

title: Add kill-worker directive to terminate a specific worker
description:
Add a 'kill-worker <worker-id>' directive that terminates a specific worker and returns its bead to the ready queue. Currently the only way to remove a stuck worker is scale down/up, which is non-deterministic and disrupts healthy workers.

## Implementation

1. Add `DirectiveKillWorker Directive = "kill-worker"` to pkg/protocol/directive.go, update Valid().
2. In dispatcher.go applyDirective (line 1770), add case for kill-worker:
   - Parse worker ID from args string
   - Look up worker in d.workers map
   - If worker has an assigned bead, return it to the queue (unassign, set bead status back to open)
   - Call d.GracefulShutdownWorker(workerID, timeout) — do NOT respawn
   - Decrement target worker count by 1 (net effect: pool shrinks by 1, like a targeted scale-down)
   - Return ACK with detail: 'killed worker <id>, bead <bead-id> returned to queue'
3. If worker ID not found, return error ACK.
